channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: What Happened on Day 95 of the War in Ukraine
item.description: As his military announced a counteroffensive around the southern port city of Kherson, President Volodymyr Zelensky made a rare visit to frontline positions. European leaders are gathering in Brussels on Monday for a two-day summit on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier holding a Stinger anti-aircraft missile at a defensive position near Russian forces in the eastern Donetsk region on Sunday.

item.title: A Russian Plane Crashed Into a House. Death Was Parceled Out Randomly.
item.description: Some fortuitous timing in doing chores saved a family that lived in the Ukrainian city of Chernihiv. A few blocks away, things turned out very differently.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yulia Hrebnyeva amid the wreckage of a Russian warplane that crashed into her family’s home in Chernihiv, Ukraine, in March. “The bricks were just pouring down,” she said. “Everything started to shake.”

item.title: As Ukraine Fights, Does the E.U. Owe It Membership?
item.description: Brussels supports Kyiv’s battle against Russia, but gaining full membership to the bloc could take years. Is there another way to bind Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia to Europe?
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers last week aboard an armored vehicle heading toward the front line near Kramatorsk, in Ukraine’s eastern Donetsk region.

item.title: Canada’s Military, Where Sexual Misconduct Went to the Top, Looks for a New Path
item.description: A report by a former Supreme Court justice due out Monday will offer recommendations to turn around pervasive sexual assault and harassment.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Chris Wattie/Reuters
item.media:description: Jonathan Vance, then chief of Canada’s defense staff, in Ottawa in 2018.

item.title: In Colombia, a Leftist and a Right-Wing Populist Head for June Runoff
item.description: The results in the first round of voting delivered a stunning blow to Colombia’s dominant conservative political class.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Joaquin Sarmiento/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Counting ballots at a polling station in Medellín, Colombia, on Sunday.

item.title: Hurricane Agatha Is Set to Hit Southern Mexico Today
item.description: With sustained winds of up to 110 miles per hour, Agatha, the first named storm in the eastern Pacific this year, was threatening the Mexican state of Oaxaca on Monday, forecasters said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Jesus Torres/Reuters
item.media:description: Cacahoatan in southern Mexico where Hurricane Agatha is expected to make landfall later on Monday. Forecasters warn the storm could trigger floods and mudslides.

item.title: Nepal Plane Crash: At Least 14 Bodies Are Recovered
item.description: The plane went down in bad weather on Sunday while carrying passengers to Jomsom, a tourist destination popular with trekkers.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: Fishtail Air Pvt Ltd Captain Nikalas Fjellgren, via Reuters
item.media:description: Plane parts and other debris scattered at the crash site of the Tara Air plane near the village of Thasang, Nepal, on Monday.

item.title: A Cafe in Philippines is Devoted to Duterte’s Drug War Victims
item.description: Served along with the lattes are personal stories from the staff, who are relatives of those who died in some of the thousands of extrajudicial killings in the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Hannah Reyes Morales for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customers of Silingan Coffee and relatives of Silingan’s staff outside the coffee shop in Quezon City, the Philippines.

item.title: Lavish Projects and Meager Lives: The Two Faces of a Ruined Sri Lanka
item.description: A frenzy of building on borrowed money in the Rajapaksa family’s home district illustrates the hubris and mismanagement that led the country into economic collapse.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Skandha Gunasekara and Atul Loke
item.media:description: Roshan Sellahenadi covered a statue of D.A. Rajapaksa, the patriarch of Sri Lanka’s ruling family, that protesters had destroyed. Mr. Sellahenadi’s family had contributed money to build it.

item.title: In Colombia, a Leftist and a Right-Wing Populist Move on to June Runoff
item.description: Two anti-establishment candidates, Gustavo Petro, a leftist, and Rodolfo Hernández, a right-wing businessman and former mayor, captured the top two spots in Sunday’s presidential election.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Chelo Camacho/Reuters

item.title: Colombia a segunda vuelta: un candidato de izquierda y un populista de derecha se enfrentarán en junio
item.description: Dos candidatos antisistema, Gustavo Petro, de izquierda, y Rodolfo Hernández, de derecha, alcanzaron los dos primeros lugares en las elecciones presidenciales del domingo.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Federico Rios para The New York Times
item.media:description: Votación en el norte del Cauca, en Colombia

item.title: Afghanistan Tries to Stamp Out Opium Again
item.description: The multibillion-dollar trade has survived previous bans. Now, the Taliban are going after solar-powered water pumps to try to dry up poppy crops in the middle of a national economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Denton, David Zucchino and Yaqoob Akbary
item.category: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Farmers harvesting opium from a field that was irrigated with a solar-powered water pump in April in Kandahar Province.

item.title: As Boris Johnson Stumbles, Labour Struggles to Offer a Clear Message
item.description: Out of power for 12 years, Britain’s Labour Party has made some gains, but its message hasn’t won back the rust belt regions that abandoned it in the last election.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Anthony Devlin/Getty Images
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, the leader of the Labour Party, speaking to supporters in Carlisle, England, after local elections this month.

item.title: Pope Francis Announces 21 New Cardinals
item.description: The new “princes of the church” hail from places like India, Nigeria, Singapore and South Korea. They will be among those who help choose a new pope.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Vincenzo Pinto/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Pope Francis greeting the Roman Catholic faithful on Sunday from the window of the apostolic palace overlooking St. Peter’s Square at the Vatican.

item.title: At Dublin Airport, Staff Shortages Lead to Travel Chaos
item.description: More than 1,000 passengers missed flights there in a day, part of a spate of similar difficulties across Europe as demand for travel surges.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Clodagh Kilcoyne/Reuters
item.media:description: Passengers at Dublin Airport in December. “Well over” 1,000 passengers missed their flights on Sunday, according to its operator.

item.title: Explosion Hits Russian-Occupied Melitopol
item.description: Pro-Kremlin authorities in the city blamed Ukrainian partisans for the blast, which they said had injured two people.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Alexander Zemlianichenko/Associated Press
item.media:description: A replica of the Soviet Victory banner in Melitopol in southeastern Ukraine, early this month. Russian forces claimed the city early in the war.

item.title: The Start of Summer
item.description: We’ve got some recommendations.
item.dc:creator: the staff of The Morning
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rest in Pioneer East Meadow in Golden Gate Park, San Francisco, Calif.

item.title: Holiday weekend in the U.S. resembles prepandemic times, as experts and the White House remain wary of virus risk.
item.description: While there is a rise in confirmed daily coronavirus cases and hospitalizations, Memorial Day observations are not being scrapped.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy and Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images
item.media:description: And so it began, the Memorial Day weekend on I-495 in McLean, Va., near Washington, D.C., on Friday afternoon.

item.title: Circling Sicily on Its Regional Trains
item.description: A Dutch photographer, documenting the culture of regional train travel, managed to get around the Italian island for less than $100. Here’s what she saw.
item.dc:creator: Sanne Derks

item.title: For NATO, Turkey Is a Disruptive Ally
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s block on NATO membership for Sweden and Finland is likely to be managed, but Washington and the rest of the alliance are annoyed.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Murat Cetinmuhurdar/Presidential Press Office, via Reuters
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has accused Finland and Sweden of sympathizing with the Kurdish militants he has made his main enemy.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A new front in Russia’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and Juston Jones

item.title: Indian Couple Sue Their Son for Not Giving Them a Grandchild
item.description: A couple in India are demanding that their son and daughter-in-law have a child or pay them $650,000 in damages. “This is an Indian parent thing,” their lawyer said.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: K Productions, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Sanjeev Ranjan Prasad, left, and Sadhana Prasad at a lawyer’s office in Haridwar, India, in May.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: A ‘Toothless’ Trip to Xinjiang
item.description: The U.N.’s top human rights official cozied up to Beijing on a trip to China.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Thomas Peter/Reuters
item.media:description: Police officers patrolling in Kashgar, Xinjiang, last year.

item.title: Ukraine Launches Counteroffensive on Russans in Kherson
item.description: “Hold on, Kherson, we’re coming!” the Ukrainian military declared as it pushed to retake territory in a key southern city.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in a trench on the front lines in the Donetsk region on Sunday.

item.title: Russia War Dead Tended by Ukrainian Soldiers
item.description: Ukrainians hope that if they safeguard Russia’s war dead, they will be more likely to get back their own.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Body bags holding Russian soldiers in a refrigerated train car in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: In Latin America, leftist leaders are on the rise amid widespread economic suffering.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño, Julie Turkewitz and Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gustavo Petro, center, with his wife, Verónica Alcocer, left, and Congresswoman Dorina Hernandez, right, during a campaign event this month in Cartagena.

item.title: For Russian-Speaking Ukrainians, Language Clubs Offer Way to Defy Invaders
item.description: Many Ukraine citizens speak Russian as their first language. Volunteer organizations are helping them improve their Ukrainian and abandon “the occupiers’ language.”
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bookshop in Lviv, Ukraine. In the wake of Russia’s invasion in February, language clubs have been popping up in Ukraine’s west.

item.title: A Shattered Town
item.description: Families and loved ones are leaning on each other to cope with the Texas school shooting.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Ivan Pierre Aguirre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members of Alexandria Rubio, better known as Lexi, cry at the memorial for the victims of the Robb Elementary School mass shooting early Friday morning.

item.title: Who is Federico Gutiérrez, a right-wing candidate for the president of Colombia?
item.dc:creator: Megan Janetsky
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federico Gutiérrez is supported by a conservative alliance similar to the one that helped propel the current president to office.

item.title: Plane Crashes in Nepal With 22 Aboard, Government Says
item.description: The search for the plane and its passengers and crew was being hampered by bad weather.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:credit: Niranjan Shrestha/Associated Press
item.media:description: Near Pokhara, the city in central Nepal from which the plane that went missing on Sunday took off.

item.title: Can I Stop Isolating If I’m Still Testing Positive for the Virus?
item.description: Some people may test positive for the coronavirus for 10 days or longer, but interpreting those results remains difficult, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Danielle St. Laurent for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rapid antigen tests have become useful tools for flagging people carrying high levels of the virus, but they are not perfect predictors of infectiousness.

item.title: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Traci Carl

item.title: Australia Wields a New DNA Tool to Crack Missing-Person Mysteries
item.description: The technique can predict a person’s ancestry and physical traits without the need for a match with an existing sample in a database.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Schwartz
item.media:credit: Stephanie Simcox for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jodie Ward is the director of a new Australian program using DNA phenotyping to help link missing persons with unidentified remains.

item.title: Sounds of bombardment drown out the ‘last bell’ for the final day of school in Ukraine.
item.description: On what is usually a day of festivities and fun, many of Ukraine’s students ended the academic year amid the sounds of war or from abroad.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed school that was used as a base by Russian forces in Vikhivka, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: U.N. Human Rights Chief Tempers Criticism at End of China Trip
item.description: Rights groups and overseas Uyghurs had called for vociferous condemnation of China’s policies toward minorities in the country’s far West. They were highly disappointed.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Thomas Peter/Reuters
item.media:description: Police officers patrolling in Kashgar, Xinjiang, last year.

item.title: Cardinal Angelo Sodano, Vatican Power Broker Linked With Sex Abuse Cover-Ups, Dies at 94
item.description: He rose to the second-highest-ranking position in the Roman Catholic Church, but his reputation was stained by his handling of sex-abuse cases.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gabriel Bouys/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Diplomats Fear Russia May Use Syrian Aid as Bargaining Chip in Ukraine
item.description: Countries in Europe and the Middle East could see a new surge in refugees if Russia shuts down the last humanitarian convoy route into Syria.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Aaref Watad/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Displaced residents in Syria received boxes of food in April. Experts warn that closing an aid route could force thousands of people to flee the country.

item.title: An Irish National Treasure Gets Set for a Long-Needed Restoration
item.description: The majestic Old Library at Trinity College Dublin, where some of Ireland’s most ancient and valuable books are stored, is a popular tourist attraction.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Long Room is at the heart of a $95 million conservation project at Trinity College Dublin’s Old Library.

item.title: Summer Reading
item.description: Today we look at this summer’s crop of new books.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: What Canada Doesn’t Know About Its Guns
item.description: New record-keeping requirements for nonrestricted firearms began this month, but the origins of Canada’s so-called crime guns are largely unknown.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Seized firearms were on display during a news conference with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Crime Stoppers in Surrey, British Columbia, in May 2021.

item.title: Ukrainian Orthodox Church Breaks With Moscow Over War
item.description: The Council of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church said that it disagreed with the Moscow Patriarch’s position on the war.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian Orthodox Christians observing Easter Sunday Mass in Lviv, Ukraine, in April.

item.title: The Fall of the ‘Sun King’ of French TV, and the Myth of Seduction
item.description: Patrick Poivre d’Arvor, known as a great seducer, has been accused by more than 20 women of rape, sexual assault and harassment in France’s belated #MeToo reckoning.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hélène Devynck, 55, left, a journalist who has accused Patrick Poivre d’Arvor of raping her, and Cécile Delarue, 43, a journalist who accused him of sexual harassment, this month in Paris.

item.title: Russians Crowdsource Supplies for Their Army in Ukraine
item.description: A grass-roots movement to get basic supplies to soldiers fighting in Ukraine reflects the growing recognition among Russians that their military was unprepared for major conflict.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergei Ilnitsky/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Russian soldiers in April in downtown Mariupol, Ukraine. There is growing recognition among Russians that their military was woefully underprepared for major conflict.

item.title: Margot Heuman, Who Bore Witness to the Holocaust as a Gay Woman, Dies at 94
item.description: She was a rare survivor who spoke — in recent years — of her same-sex relationship in the concentration camps, and how it sustained her.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: Italian Bishops to Examine Clerical Abuse, but Only to a Point
item.description: The Italian Bishops’ Conference on Friday presented its plan to investigate clerical abuse, but critics say it is insufficient and disappointing.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Yara Nardi/Reuters
item.media:description: Cardinal Matteo Zuppi, president of the Italian Bishops’ Conference, speaking in Rome on Friday.

item.title: Iran Seizes Two Greek Tankers in Persian Gulf
item.description: The ships were taken in retaliation for Greece last month impounding, at the request of the United States, an Iranian oil tanker, according to Iranian news reports.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Dursun Çam via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Prudent Warrior, one of the Greek-flagged oil tankers said to have been seized by Iran on Friday, sailing past Istanbul in 2019.

item.title: Iraqi Parliament Expands Law Against Normalizing Ties With Israel
item.description: The legislation, based on a similar law dating back to 1969, makes it a crime punishable by death. It makes Iraq an outlier in the Arab world, where more countries are forging diplomatic relations with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Thaier Al-Sudani/Reuters
item.media:description: Supporters of Muqtada al-Sadr celebrating in Baghdad on Thursday after Iraq’s parliament passed legislation that broadens the crime of normalizing relations with Israel.

item.title: A Putin Opponent From Russia Leads Fighters Against His Home Country
item.description: “The hottest place to fight against the regime was in Ukraine,” says a unit commander who has been a volunteer soldier for his adopted country on and off since 2015.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:description: The commander of a Ukrainian unit, who identified himself only by his code name Kandalaksha, walked through a trench system on the front lines of the Donetsk region on Sunday. He is from Russia, an anomaly in the mostly Ukrainian unit he leads.

item.title: Sensitive Iranian Military Site Was Targeted in Attack
item.description: A drone exploded at a structure in the Parchin military technology complex on Wednesday. The attack fit a pattern of past Israeli strikes on Iran.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Missiles on display in Tehran in January. Iran develops weapons technology at the nearby Parchin military complex, which was struck on Wednesday.

item.title: Russian Academics Aim to Punish Colleagues Who Backed Ukraine Invasion
item.description: A campaign is circulating a list of dozens of researchers in the hopes they will be denied the prestige of election into the Russian Academy of Sciences.
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla
item.media:credit: Felix Lipov/Alamy
item.media:description: The Russian Academy of Sciences in Moscow.

item.title: India’s Supreme Court Orders Police to Respect Prostitutes’ Rights
item.description: Though sex work is legal in the country, those who practice it often endure harassment and abuse. The justices urged the authorities to employ a more nuanced and humane approach.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Sameer Yasir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Bikas Das/Associated Press
item.media:description: A rally in Kolkata, India, in April in support of protecting the constitutional rights of sex workers.

item.title: Abba Returns to the Stage in London. Sort Of.
item.description: The Swedish superstars — or digital versions of them, at least — performed on Thursday to 3,000 enthusiastic fans with the help of 140 animators, four body doubles and $175 million.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: Pakistan Raises Fuel Prices in Effort to Stabilize Economy
item.description: The interim government’s move was seen as a bid to revive a $6 billion bailout from the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Shahzaib Akber/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Motocyclists at a gas station in Karachi, Pakistan, on Thursday night just before a fuel price increase took effect.

item.title: Displaced Ukrainians Learn to Detect Mines.
item.description: Courses in western Ukraine, meant for volunteer defenders, are now open to Ukrainian civilians whose villages have been blighted by war.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A deactivated landmine used as a teaching aid for the class.

item.title: Deep in Vatican Archives, Scholar Discovers ‘Flabbergasting’ Secrets
item.description: David Kertzer has spent decades excavating the Vatican’s hidden history, with his work winning a Pulitzer and capturing Hollywood’s attention. A new book examines Pope Pius XII’s role in the Holocaust.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: The Pope at War: The Secret History of Pius XII, Mussolini, and Hitler (Book)
item.media:credit: Massimo Berruti for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Kertzer at the library of the American Academy in Rome, after a day of scholarly investigations inside the Vatican’s archives.

item.title: The Uvalde 21: A Tribute to Victims of the Texas Shooting
item.description: Today, we mourn the victims of Uvalde.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners in Uvalde, Texas.

item.title: China Spins U.N. Human Rights Chief’s Visit as Propaganda
item.description: Michelle Bachelet’s tour includes Xinjiang, where China has been accused of genocide. The terms of her visit are unclear, and critics say Beijing is using her for propaganda.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Austin Ramzy
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Carlos Garcia Rawlins/Reuters
item.media:description: Michelle Bachelet, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, and Xi Jinping, China’s leader, on a screen in Beijing this week. Her visit has been widely publicized in China.

item.title: 11 Families in Senegal Welcomed Newborns. A Fire Left Them Devastated.
item.description: Joy over the births turned to shock and grief after a blaze swept through a neonatal ward at a hospital in Senegal. “There’s nothing we can do but suffer,” said a man who lost his grandson.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women waited for details of what had happened, and when they could retrieve the bodies of their loved ones, outside the Tivaouane hospital in Senegal on Thursday after 11 babies died in a fire there.

item.title: Global Brands Seek Clarity on Xinjiang
item.description: Companies that sourced cotton from the region in China are weighing evidence of forced labor, a lack of visibility into operations and new regulation.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Sapna Maheshwari
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Reports of forced labor of Uyghur people in Xinjiang have made retailers rethink their supply chains.

item.title: How an Organized Republican Effort Punishes Companies for Climate Action
item.description: Legislators and their allies are running an aggressive campaign that uses public money and the law to pressure businesses they say are pushing “woke” causes.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles and Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Kieran Dodds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters at the Glasgow climate summit last year. A number of banks, investors and companies pledged at the talks to cut their greenhouse gas emissions.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Economic sanctions bite in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Natalia Kolesnikova/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Commercial space for rent in downtown Moscow.
